bestBHT.bht: During a private journey, Jesus renewed his prediction of his impending death and resurrection. Urging his disciples to listen carefully, he emphasized that the Son of man would be delivered into the hands of men. Despite the glory they had witnessed, Jesus wanted them to remember the future darkness he would endure. Taking time in seclusion to instruct and teach, Jesus highlighted the significance of his resurrection after three days, offering comfort and hope to his disciples.

Henry Alford: SECOND ANNOUNCEMENT OF HIS DEATH AND RESURRECTION. Matt. xvii. 22, 23. Luke ix. 43–45, where see notes, as this account is included in the two others.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let these sayings sink down into your ears.
The Son of man shall be delivered into the hands of men.

Be not carried off your feet by all that grandeur of Mine which ye have lately witnessed, but bear in mind what I have already told you and now distinctly repeat, that that Sun in whose beams ye now rejoice is soon to set in midnight gloom.
Marvin Vincent: He sought seclusion because he was engaged for the time in instructing.
The teaching was the continuation of the 'began to teach'.
The present tense is graphic. The future is realized by the Lord as already present.
Philip Schaff: For he taught, or, ‘was teaching,’ habitually, during this private journey.
Archibald T. Robertson: He was renewing again definitely the prediction of his death in Jerusalem some six months ahead as he had done before."
Jesus foretells his resurrection 'after three days' ('the third day').
John Gill: The son of man is delivered into the hands of men: in one of Beza's copies it is read, "sinful men", as in Luke 24:7 and so the Persic version reads here, and adds rebellious.
This is represented as if it was already done, because it was determined and agreed upon, that it should be.
This Christ always takes care to mention, for the comfort of his disciples, when he tells them of his death.

bhtAttempts.bht: As Jesus and his disciples traveled privately, he took the opportunity to reiterate his impending death and resurrection to them. He urged them to pay close attention to his words, as he emphasized that the Son of man would soon be delivered into the hands of men. Jesus wanted his disciples to understand that despite the grandeur they had witnessed in his ministry, his ultimate destiny was to suffer and die on their behalf. He sought seclusion because he was engaged in instructing and teaching them about the future events that lay ahead. Jesus highlighted the importance of his resurrection after three days, a hope that would provide comfort and assurance to his disciples amidst the impending darkness of his death.

During a private journey, Jesus renewed his prediction of his impending death and resurrection. Urging his disciples to listen carefully, he emphasized that the Son of man would be delivered into the hands of men. Despite the glory they had witnessed, Jesus wanted them to remember the future darkness he would endure. Taking time in seclusion to instruct and teach, Jesus highlighted the significance of his resurrection after three days, offering comfort and hope to his disciples.

As Jesus and his disciples traveled privately, he emphasized the importance of his impending death and resurrection. He urged them to pay close attention as he reiterated that the Son of man would soon be delivered into the hands of men. Despite the grandeur they had witnessed in his ministry, Jesus wanted his disciples to remember that his ultimate destiny was to suffer and die. Taking time in seclusion, he continued to teach them about the future events that lay ahead, including his resurrection after three days.

During a private journey, Jesus emphasized to his disciples the significance of his impending death and resurrection. Urging them to pay close attention, he reiterated that the Son of man would be delivered into the hands of men. Despite the grandeur they had witnessed, Jesus wanted his disciples to remember that his ultimate destiny was to suffer and die. Taking time in seclusion to instruct and teach, he highlighted the importance of his resurrection after three days, providing them with comfort and reassurance.

While traveling privately, Jesus reminded his disciples about his forthcoming death and resurrection. He urged them to carefully consider his words, emphasizing that the Son of man would be delivered into the hands of men. Jesus wanted his disciples to understand that despite the grandeur they had witnessed, his ultimate fate was one of suffering and death. Taking advantage of their seclusion, Jesus continued to teach and instruct them about the events that awaited him, including his resurrection after three days.
